talk to you about drones, landscapes,
and chainsaws.

So there are three key elements to
creating a workflow like this. Uh the
first is having accurate site models.

The second is using precise and flexible

So, at some point in the design process,
you need a drawing called a survey. Um,
I'm not sure how many of you actually
are in the AC industry, so I'll explain
a little bit about what a survey is. A
survey is a a really precise drawing
that shows the outline of existing site
features such as buildings, roads,
walkways, even things underground and
topographic features like contours.
And surveys are expensive. Um we
ultimately do get a survey done
professionally in every project we do.
Um, but sometimes, uh, you want to get
accurate site information that's, uh,
not going to a professional survey right
away. And you have some options. You can
visit the site yourself, but if it's far
away, maybe not everyone on your team

like a survey. Um, and also communicate

Uh costs because this is information

aerial surveying. So the drone we use is
the DJI Trice 4 Enterprise. It's a
fairly new drone. We have also used the
Mavic 3 Enterprise before. And when you
buy one of these drones, it comes with a
controller and all the software you need
to do the scan. Uh the key features on
the drone uh are an RTK system and a
mechanical shutter which is most drones
uh consumer drones have a rolling
shutter which will create motion blur on
the photographs which is not great for
photoggramometry reconstruction. So it
doesn't really matter what drone you get
as long as it has these two features. Um
the Matrice 4E is around $5,000. Uh the
Mavic 3 Enterprise is probably around
3,000 now. And I'm sure you can find a
lot cheaper alternatives than that even
when you weigh that AC cost against the
cost of a single survey. Sometimes it it
pays off. So um then you also need a
base station. A base station is
essentially a tripod with an RTK system
on top. Pretty transportable.
And um we use the DRTK3.
We Yeah,
RTK stands for real time kinematic. It's
um it's it's a fancy It's a fancy GPS
system. So, compared to the GPS system
on your phone, which will give you meter
level accuracy, it will give you
centimeter level accuracy, which is
really important when creating drawings
like this uh because you need to
actually locate them on the real world
somewhere.
Um
we the Eml reach is also um popular and
these are around $2,000 or less to get
that whole setup. And then you need
reality scan. And so depending on your
business, uh this the cost of reality
scan varies. It could be free, could be
paid. Um and it's not very popular in
the aerial surveying community, but it's
really powerful. Um and I suggest that a
lot of people start using it more for
this purpose.
So the capturing of the data is really
easy. Um on the controller, you
essentially draw an outline of the area
you want to scan and uh you adjust a few
settings similar to photoggramometry
settings.
And um the drone takes off, it takes all
the photos and when it runs out of
battery, it comes back and you replace
the battery. It goes exactly back to the
location that it left off. And then it
stores all the photos on an SD card. A
flight like this took about 30 minutes
to complete, which is really fast if you
think about how long it would take to
survey a site that large. And I'll show
you an example here of an 18 acres site
that we flew in about an hour. So,
um, once you have your SD card full of
photos, you go into reality scan and
there's a map wizard tool and it
essentially will take the photos that
you used RTK on and position them in the
real world and create a an alignment for
you. And I really don't change the
settings often unless there's many
issues.
And with that um, with that alignment,
you can create a 3D model. So here's
that 18acre site and all those little
dots are the drone photos.
Then you create what's called an
orthographic projection. Orthographic
projection is a uh geo reference aerial
photograph that's true to scale. So you
can use this to take measurements.
But what we're mainly using it for is to
generate contours.
If you think about that survey I showed
you, it had all sorts of informations
about the outline of buildings and
walkways. And you can use the photograph
um in a concept design phase to to to
figure out where that those parts are.
But the the contours is something that
the photograph doesn't show. So, reality
scan uh has a cut contours tool, and it
sort of works because if you notice that
building there, if the if you didn't see
the building, the contours here uh
represent something that would be a
really weird looking mountain.
So, you can fix that in reality scan.
There's a tool called the AI classify
tool. It will go through all your photos
and try to find buildings, cars, trees,
um, features that don't represent the
ground and manually mask them out.
And when you do that and you regenerate
the contours,
it's okay, but it's still way too much
detail. If you give this to landscape
architect, they're going to be a little
bit annoyed at how jaggedy these are.
And also we're still the AI classify
tool is still missing quite a lot of
information. Um we're still capturing

So what do we do? The trick is really to
think like a surveyor would and just
create the information you actually

yourself, but uh maybe one day reality

So, with the alignment in reality scan
and the orthographic photo, another
thing it generates for you is called a

and uh it looks like this
where those black splotches are trees
and the cars and everything are
included. We're we really are concerned
with just the raw data.
And what we want to do is take a plane
that's the same dimensions as that
height map, the same real world
dimensions, and use it to displace that
plane. So each pixel in that height map
represents a certain uh altitude and we
can use that to displace this plane. And
what that creates is a really simple
representation of our site that's super
clean. And
now we can start to think like a
surveyor. Surveyor would go around the
site and they would use a rover and take
um points and sample points at different
locations. And we have a virtual site so
we can just do that virtually. So, we
can take uh points at a specific
interval, specific pattern, and sample
them. And we just don't sample the
trees, and we don't sample the cars. And
there's certain things we're going to
have to add, like we want to add samples
where the retaining walls are, where the
road is, where the curbs are.
And then from those points, we can mesh
it. And this is um what if you've uh
received a survey before, you sometimes
get a tin. And this is essentially a
tin. And so this is how you get a tin
from Reality Scan.
And you cut your contours from the tin.
And now you have clean contours.
And finally, you can overlay that back
on a drawing.
And everyone's happy.

so modeling landscapes is really
difficult, especially if you're coming

you might ask, why don't we just use the

There's many reasons. Mainly, they're
not precise enough for what we're doing.
Um, we really hope that one day they can

find. Um, but they're not precise enough
for us right now. They also struggle to
create clean edges. If you're a person
that works with in rendering um and you
want to create a sharp transition
between grass and a walkway, uh there's
limitations to vertex painting. You can
never get a real sharp edge. We've used
Unreal before, so we were trying a
runtime virtual textures as a way to go

edges is quite difficult. And um
these sculpting tools aren't really well

there's three steps we use to creating

biggest tips are definitely wait for a
good scanning weather. Like every

scan some, an object like that takes
maybe 10 minutes to scan, to walk around

reconstruction for something like this
on a 4090 is around an hour to get the
high quality 3D model. And then my other
suggestion is you buy or make a coded
target scale bar. So I bought these ones
from paleo3d.com
and essentially it's two pairs of coded
targets and Reality Scan can locate
these targets in your photos. And then
on that scale bar it says 0.4 meters and
0.5 meters. So we can tell reality scan
exactly the dimensions between those
points. And so in a matter of seconds,
you can scale your model to real world
dimensions. This is great for rendering,
but also if you want to uh if you're
like us and you're working with a lot of
organic features, um maybe uh so in
playground design, I didn't talk about
this too much, but there's specific
areas around everything that are called
safety zones. They need to be very
precise. we can't have uh a a child
falling and and hurting themselves. But
when you're working with uh trees and
they're completely different each time,
it's really hard to figure that out in
in drawing. So, we also use photo
scanning as a way to to figure out that
information.
And then the cleanup process. So in

basically get your high poly model,
close any holes.
Then

and you do what's called rettopology
